headline: Spicy Thai Basil Chicken (Pad Krapow Gai)
description: Chef John's version of this classic Thai dish, made with freshly chopped chicken thighs and fresh basil, has a rich sauce that cooks down into a caramelized glaze.

video.description: Chef John's all-time favorite Thai dish!
video.name: Spicy Thai Basil Chicken (Pad Krapow Gai)

name: Spicy Thai Basil Chicken (Pad Krapow Gai)
recipeIngredient: 1 tablespoon soy sauce, or as needed
1 pound skinless, boneless chicken thighs, coarsely chopped
2 tablespoons minced Thai chilies, Serrano, or other hot pepper
1 cup very thinly sliced fresh basil leaves

recipeInstructions.text: Whisk chicken broth, oyster sauce, soy sauce, fish sauce, white sugar, and brown sugar together in a bowl until well blended.
Heat large skillet over high heat. Drizzle in oil. Add chicken and stir fry until it loses its raw color, 2 to 3 minutes.
Stir in shallots, garlic, and sliced chilies. Continue cooking on high heat until some of the juices start to caramelize in the bottom of the pan, about 2 or 3 more minutes.
Add about a tablespoon of the sauce mixture to the skillet; cook and stir until sauce begins to caramelize, about 1 minute.
Pour in the rest of the sauce. Cook and stir until sauce has deglazed the bottom of the pan. Continue to cook until sauce glazes onto the meat, 1 or 2 more minutes. Remove from heat.
Stir in basil. Cook and stir until basil is wilted, about 20 seconds. Serve with rice.

review.reviewBody: Easy to make taste delicious threw in extra Thai chili to boost the heat.

Can’t go wrong with Chef John. Actually used the leftovers to make soup (add coconut milk and chicken broth, shredded carrots and kale or whatever other herbs/vegetables would go well). May not be a real recipe but it was awesome.
Very easy to cook. And if you follow the instructions accurately, it tastes absolutely traditional and refreshing.
My new favorite recipe !! LOVE IT!!
This is one of my families favorites. I use serrano peppers, less fish sauce and more soy sauce. I also mix in Sweet Thai chili sauce which balances out the heat and makes it perfect.
This is such a great recipe. I'm not a cook or chef by any means but I followed this recipe step by step and it turned out fantastic! My wife loved it too. Great job and thank you!
Used chopped chicken thighs, followed recipe to a T and came out delicious! The family loved it!

This was really good, only one issue I couldn't get the sauce to thicken up like the recipe said. doesn't matter I guess it was really good the way it turned out. I made some rice noodles to go along with it, they were ok. I used Serrano peppers to mince them I used my mortar smooshed them after cutting them up, I left one pepper with seeds. The other 2 were seeded this was a very nice heat.

Easy to make and authentic tasting with Thai basil. I didn’t have fresh red chilies but dried red pepper was good substitute. I didn’t follow the recipe exactly by using chicken tenders cut up in small chunks and marinating them the sauce first before cooking. Garlic salt and black pepper also help enhance the flavor. Probably would have turned out even better with Thai chilies.

I've prepared this meal twice for my family and the second time was much better than the first. On the second attempt, I added more soy sauce than required and didn't hold back on the peppers. I realized the first attempt the juices from the chicken took over when adding the sauce but on the second attempt, I simplify raised the heat to high. Everything came out great. My wife said it was spicy but not overbearing. This definitely beats $23 takeout.

I used duck fat and I grew Holy Basil hydroponically, specifically for this dish. (I've got a Ton!) Fabulous flavor. Definitely worth seeking out Holy Basil. It is pretty easy to grow from seed, I'll make pesto with the rest.
Didn't taste that good was too sweet and the thighs also made it unappetizing

I liked the recipe and other recipes call for similar ingredients. I thought the end result was a little fishy, so I'd halve the oyster and fish sauce. I added extra chillis, sriachia and soy sauce. I think it turned out much better than when I orginally tasted it. I'd definitely make again with more modifications.
Really good, and easy to prepare! I used Poblano peppers (so it was not so spicy for the kids). Works really well to use for "lettuce wraps"
This Spicy Thai chicken receipe is really good, After coming from office for our dinner I made this its easy to make and less time consuming and the chicken is really delicious.

First off this is a fantastic recipe as written. Rave reviews!! But I did see another review which warned people that it’s difficult to achieve the same level of heat that this recipe requires from a traditional residential grade stove and I agree. I’m a real amateur but I’ve tried this several times and I think I found a way to get around this issue. 1. Drain excess water from the chicken after its cooked through, before adding the aromatics. 2. Triple the sauce - you will need extra to get the best caramelized glaze on the chicken and it’s so delicious you will want more for your rice or noodles! 3. Take the glazing slow. Add just as much as you need to deglaze the pan then once it evaporates, repeat until it’s gone. 4. You may want to incorporate a little corn starch slurry into the sauce at the very end for extra thickness but if you drain the liquid at the beginning it’s probably not necessary. This dish has gotten the highest of praise from my boyfriend and he requests it frequently! You really can’t go wrong as written but I added red bell pepper with the aromatics and used 5 thai chilis (perfect medium heat - could have done one or two more for a legitimately hot Thai dish). I have previously used 4 Serrano chilis instead and that upped the spiciness considerably. This is sooooo good!!!
Incredible. I substituted lean ground pork for the chicken and it was amazing. Better than my go to Thai restaurant.
Krapow has always been one of my favorites. I had a wonderful Thai friend who would make it for me. This recipe is super easy but it tastes absolutely authentic.

Really delicious and easy. I used my Cuisinart and processed 1 lb skinless, boneless chicken thighs, so it looked about like ground chicken. I followed the recipe pretty much but used a large jalapeno (seeded) which I grow. I tasted the sauce before dumping in and decided to add a splash of rice wine vinegar. Made jasmine rice at the same time as the recipe, so everything was ready in about 20 minutes. We have lots of late summer basil growing, and I might have had a bit more than one cup. I chopped 1/2 cup of low-sodium peanuts and added them to the top. All in all, really really nice. The chicken without the rice could be used in lettuce wraps. Just double the sauce, so there is plenty for dipping.
So tasty. Made it just as described and it was delicious.

I am a huge fan of Pad Krapow Gai and get it almost everytime I get Thai food. The ground chicken is definitely the way I prefer it. Great recipe and instructions, only thing I'd say is add more sugar, soy sauce or maybe sweet chili thai sauce as mine was super hot with Serrano/Jalapeno's. I'd back off on the fish sauce to avoid it from being too salty. Thanks, great recipe I'll add to my repertoire.

This is REALLY GOOD! I added zucchini for some veg and I did double the sauce. Although it seems OVERsaucy so next time I’ll leave it as is. I was worried the basil would be too much but it’s delicious! Also next time I’ll add more peppers! I was being conservative, could have easily used more.

Wayyyyyyy too salty tasting. I wished I listened to other reviews and cut down on the soy sauce. Also, when I added the broth to the soy, oyster sauce mix, it got “watery” and lost the ability to really flavor and color the meat to the fun darker brown look I was anticipating from the video. I really followed this recipe closely so a little disappointed it wasn’t better tasting.
Outstanding! I added red bell pepper thinly sliced to add a little color, flavor and a vegetable.
Awesome taste ...I will lighte up the fish sauce since I think it was too salty tasting

This is a great dish but, of course, it's not truly authentic without Thai holy basil. I found a local Asian store that sells frozen cooked Chinese duck, and I've been making this dish with this, instead of chicken, for a few years now. It's still not authentic, of course, but what I've found is that the star anise/five spice flavours from the duck provide a similar aniseed-like flavour to that of holy basil. It works REALLY well. So now, when I cook this dish with chicken, I add just a pinch of five spice to the sauce mix. I just adds a whole different dimension to the taste without being too obvious. I also add blanched round beans, just 'cause I like a few greens in my dish, and I always have to have the fried egg on top... it just has to be there! LOL

Very good flavor and I’ll make it again. Next time I will double the sauce recipe and maybe include a veggie - may not be authentic but I think it would amp it up a bit. Update: I've now made this several times. We LOVE IT. I do double the sauce and add broccoli. It is excellent. I've just discovered fresh rice noodles (in the refrigerator section of the international grocery) and it absorbs the yummy sauce really well. I also get the thai basil at the int'l grocery. yum yum!
Instead of using regular soy sauce, use dark mushroom soy sauce. It will give the dish a beautiful dark color. Also, before you put the mixed sauce in, let the juices from the chicken reduce.

Foolproof recipe & I've tried several times & followed to a T. Its always the same yummilicious taste, quite similar to the Thai restaurant I usually patronised. Thank you for this awesome recipe as its easy & straightforward to follow.

Made exactly as written with a mix of Thai basil and Genovese basil from my garden and it was SUPERB. It is rare, in my experience, to be able to recreate the depth of flavor found in popular Asian dishes without all the time and tools. This recipe is the exception. We used one serrano with seeds, half a deseeded jalapeno, and a diced red bell pepper and were satisfied with the heat. I may add the whole jalapeno next time. TIPS: 1. Be sure to cook the mixture, stirring OFTEN and vigorously until the water is cooked out before adding your sauce. 2. Use a high-walled, heat conductive pot such as a wok or dutch oven so that you can crank the heat and stir aggressively to replicate the wok flavor and technique. 3. Take the time to chop the chicken. It's really worth it.
Great recipe. Came out just like how my favorite Thai restaurant makes it.
This was awesome, I love Chef John and his recipe videos. This turned out almost exact to his. I did add a little sesame oil, scallions, red peppers and sriracha. Will double the batch next time. 😃
So awesome this is the best dish ever

This was delicious! I doubled the sauce, as others recommended. I didn’t end up using it all, but I used most of it. I had never cooked with fish sauce, so I was a bit nervous. So I went a little less on the fish sauce, I used about 2.5 tsp’s (because I doubled the sauce) instead of 4. I also used Serrano peppers, we are fans of spicy, so next time I will definitely add more Serrano pepper. We will definitely be making this again! Thank you for the recipe Chef John!

Not our favorite. Not saucy, not flavorful except for the basil explosion. We love basil, we love Thai food, but this was a miss. Followed recipe to the letter. Leaves an everlasting basil flavor in your mouth. My husband has Covid, and he was worried that he might lose his sense of taste but this dish blew his palate out with basil so clearly he will be fine.
Absolutely delicious! Chef John never fails at creating authentic tasting dishes!

Liked this but did find it a little salty. I doubled the sauce and used ground turkey cause its all I had on hand. added sauteed mushrooms, Bok choy and snap peas. Served it over basmatic rice, will make this again.
Added green beans to replicate the first time i had this dish in Belgium

I made this for my son and husband, who is an Executive Chef 30+ years, and he absolutely loved it. I didn’t have fish sauce so I used soy sauce and black vinegar, 1 teaspoon of each. Next time I will probably double the sauce recipe because our son loves the sauce. This is definitely in my rotation for my family. I wish I would have taken a picture.
Turned out Amazing!!!
This dish was a huge hit. Restaurant quality allowing you to adjust heat profile. Prep work is alot! But worth it.

I was looking for recipes to use the Thai Basil I'm growing in my garden. I didn't have any oyster or fish sauce on hand, so I substituted Gluten free Hoisin sauce. I used Mike's Hot Honey instead of the sugars since the peppers I had weren't very spicy. This is delicious. I can't wait to try it again as written.
We're trying to limit our carb intake, so I made this as a filling for lettuce wraps, and my wife LOVED it.

This dish was excellent! As good as Simply Thai restaurant. I did double up on everything, except the chicken and soy sauce. I like a lot of juice. Also, used 1/2 Tbs red crushed peppers instead of raw peppers. Added 2 red bell peppers because that's how they have it in the restaurant. Delicious!
Incredible.
Great recipe. Definitely watch the video for some great preparation and cooking tips. Next time I'll add some vegetables to stretch it out and keep it to two Thai peppers to moderate the heat.

Straight-forward and easy-to-follow recipe. I followed the recipe as written. OK but bland. It needs something. Don't know what but it does. First time I've given a Chef John recipe less than five stars.
Instead of fish sauce, I used an extra teaspoon soy and an extra teaspoon oyster sauce. So, so good.
Amazing ??
i used red pepper flakes instead of Serrano pepper as I didn't have it. Yummy.
Easy to make and everyone liked it
Perfect!

Great busy week night recipe!!! Chef John listed 25 minutes prep total prep and cook and he was spot on. This was my first time using oyster and fish sauce so I used another reviewers suggestion of using half the amounts. Tasted delicious. Chopped my chicken meat smaller than bite size, liked the texture and it really took on the sauce flavor. Growing fresh herbs this winter so we used our Thai basil and it added a really nice flavor. Thank you Chef John for sharing this recipe. Will be making this again!

Easy to make, excellent flavor. I did add a green pepper, and half a teaspoon of cornstarch to the sauce to help it thicken in the pan. I used a jalapeno pepper and regular basil. I will be adding this dish to my regular rotation. It was sweet and spicy and just like the stuff from my local restaurant. Yum!
We made this, but we searched it over cauliflower rice and lettuce wraps. We occasionally use ground Turkey as well.
I loved this and so did my husband! Next time I will include peanuts and/or diced water chesnuts...just to have some different textures...but it was so flavorful and will add this to my rotation!

First time making this, but definitely will not be the last. This recipe turned out really good. I did a couple different things to it, but stuck pretty much to the recipe. I used a grinder and ground the chicken up. Hit that in a wok with the oil until the raw color went away. Added more oil and cooked the shallots, garlic and chilies until fragrant. I doubled The recipe so I added about a quarter cup of the sauce. Let that evaporate and caramelize. Then added the rest of the sauce and cook that for a minute. Add the chicken back in and let it simmer until there wasn’t really any liquid. A couple more tablespoons of soy sauce, and a little bit of salt. Then fold in the basil. You absolutely have to add a fried egg on top though.
Absolutely as simple to make and as delicious as I expected it to be. Chef John is always my first search when I’m looking for a new recipe.

I look forward to growing thai basil every year just so I can cook this recipe! My wife and I love the flavors. Make sure the basil is packed tightly when measuring though. It may seem like too much, but like spinach, wilts substantially when cooked and will provide just the right amount when finished.
This Spicy Thai Basil Chicken recipe is so good! I love it a bit more spicy and siracha (which I bought at Karman Foods) is a great option, too! It's absolutely flavorful and delicious.

This dish is excellent. The first time that I made it, I doubled everything. When I make it now, I usually triple the sauce and double the meat, so that there will be extra sauce to use on rice and veggies. I’ve made this recipe by stir frying finely chopped chicken thighs, stir frying 1 inch dice chicken thighs, and when making a large batch, have even broiled whole chicken thighs and then chopped them and proceeded with the recipe. It was delicious every time! Great recipe!
Fantastic recipe! This has become one of our favorite dinners! The Thai Basil imparts such a wonderful flavor and aroma.
This was just amazing! Definitely a keeper that I will make often. Thanks so much for all your great recipes, Chef John!
So amazing. I actually forgot the basil the first time! It's better with it, but also scrummy without. Enjoy!

Excellent base recipe. Tonight I added lots of stir fry veggies and doubled (or tripled?) the sauce as well as using 3 lbs chopped up chicken thighs. Thanks Chef John for another family and company go to recipe!

OMG so good. I do not typically cook Asian food, but was able to follow this recipe and look like a pro. The flavor and spice level were out of this world and my family loved it. Never any leftovers when I make this one. Thank you for this recipe!

Hands-down one of my favorite dishes! Do prep your ingredients before you start, because it comes together very quickly. The prep is the longest part of this dish. But excellent flavor! I usually triple the sauce just because I like it a little saucier. I also find that I have to cook the chicken liquid down before I add the sauce ingredients. So I tend to cook mine a little bit longer to cook off all that liquid before creating the sauce. If need be you can pull the chicken out of the pan and cook down the liquid n the pan before creating your sauce. That way you don’t over cook your chicken. I’ve also tried it with chicken breast but it is definitely better with thighs.

Delicious! However, take care with the the chilis! Based on a Google search, I determined that Thai bird peppers are 4x as hot as serrano peppers. I used a half tablespoon of minced Thai bird peppers with the seeds removed. I can't imagine how hot this would have been if I'd used 2 tablespoons of minced whole bird peppers!!

Great dish! Was looking for a non-pasta recipe to use up the basil from my garden. The dish I made with this recipe tasted much better than the expensive thai basil entree I had not too long ago at a decent restaurant. My husband does not like fishy tasting food but enjoyed this recipe by Chef John. Looking forward to the lunch comments in the break room tomorrow. We will definitely be making this again. I know the oyster sauce and fish sauce look like scary ingredients but they are necessary and provide depth of flavor. This recipe is very simple and does not disappoint!
Perfection easy and yummy

so firstly let me say, this was delicious. i used more chicken so i doubled the recipe. as others said, my sauce never caramelized and i had WAY too much broth from cooking the chicken. i followed all the steps exactly. so next time i will do what others said and not add chicken broth to the liquid mixture and also make less of that. i will use what i have from the pan. it was a delicious meal i just knocked off a star for being too soupy. not sure how chef john got his to be a different sort of sauce in his video. but i would def make this again.

I don't usually post reviews - good or bad, but I had to post one for this amazing recipe. Pad Krapow is my favorite Thai dish and this recipe totally nails it. Delicious flavor. I made it with chicken breast instead and it was perfect.
great dish!
I loved this! I doubled the recipe so I could be sure to have leftovers. Adjust the Thai red chilis to suit your desired heat level - keeping in mind they are very hot!

Incredibly tasty. Restaurant quality goodness. I tried putting the chicken thighs in the freezer as suggested, but the chicken never got hard enough to make cutting/grounding it very easy. Instead of ground chicken, i cut it into about 1/2 inch pieces which was great - got good seared edges and a nice texture. Also, the chicken skin was really tough to cut through, so I removed it completely from the thighs, used scissors to cut it up into smaller pieces and cooked it in the oil first before adding the chicken which added a lot of flavor. Also, we added quartered Japanese eggplant after the chicken was cooked but before adding the peppers, garlic and shallots. It was insanely good!
I have basil growing in a planter out back, so when I saw this recipe, I thought yum. And the recipe didn't disappoint. It is awesome!

I followed the recipe - mostly follow the first time and then adjust to my liking.

I agree with some of the other reviews
I had to drain liquids to get to caramelize
I will greatly reduce fish sauce to maybe none- oyster sauce not sure yet.
The dish needs a crunch going to try green peppers late in cooking, maybe water chestnuts? I did not do egg on top but not think that a necessity. Has the basis of a great dish; I'm not there yet!
Very important for this recipe is to use fresh Thai peppers. It was absolutely delicious with those and if you use the wrong pepper I could see it turning out bland. bug hit in my household!
pad krapow gai is one of my favorite dishes and this recipe is my goto. it's the favorite dish of mine at my house.
Love Thai food but Didn't like this at all. Not Much flavor, and very sweet and salty
Excellent recipe - plus here's a tip - if you have a little leftover (in my case about a cup) you can drop it in a pot with some broth and pasta - it makes an excellent soup!
Delicious, will definitely make this again!! I made a smidge extra sauce and it turned out perfect, flavorful, just the right amount of spicy.

This is a tasty variation on the original. However There is no way the word pad should be in the name of this recipe. Something got lost in translation. Pad is the Thai word for noodles so you can’t call it pad if you are serving it on rice instead of noodles. Kow is the Thai word for rice so you should replace the word pad with kow in order to correctly translate the name of this dish from Thai. I prefer to use sugar in the raw because it is the closest thing we can easily purchase to the original Thai cane sugar.

This is one of my favorite of Chef John's recipes. I have made this several times, and it's always good. I use ground chicken, though, rather than chopping chicken thighs as Chef recommends - I tried it that way the first time, and didn't feel it made enough of a difference.
I substitute oyster sauce with sweet soy sauce and added a little bit of dark soy sauce to make it darker.

The fish and oyster sauce COMPLETELY ruin it. Probably the most awful dish I have ever cooked (and I love Chef John!)

Do not be fooled by the 5 stars. My house still smells horrible from this stuff from last night!
I double down on the sauce and added fresh mushrooms, Serrano peppers and a tbs of siracha. Spicy, but good..hmmmm

Excellent, I actually had no chicken at home and used ground beef instead 
I must say i was pleasantly surprised and my family loved it!
Easy to make and everyone wanted more!
It was absolutely delicious! My extremely picky husband went back for seconds and thirds! I used ground chicken breast instead but otherwise followed the recipe and loved it!

I was doubtful about the flavor using sweet basil but since I couldn't find Thai basil, I proceeded as written. It is delicious and a big hit with my family! I did make these "additions": doubled the sauce (so I didn't get that glaze) and added a couple of handfuls of raw broccoli after adding the rest of the sauce. This will be requested around my house, I'm sure.

We love Chef John's recipes and this was no exception. I added chopped peanuts at the end for crunch, I definitely recommend that addition. I was also looking for an excuse to use actual Thai basil from my garden and that really took this dish to the next level! Thanks Chef John!
This is the best recipe! Oyster sauce adds that special touch

Taste was great only change was more peppers to spice dish 
Made several times quick and easy.
I've made this twice. It wasn't spicy enough for my taste, and I think next time I will reduce or eliminate the fish sauce.

I love almost everything Chef John posts. I forgot to thaw the chicken so I made this with ground turkey and it was shockingly good. I doubled the sauce but needed to triple or quadruple it. You need to make sure to cook it long enough and hot enough to get crispy.

Never made Thai at home but will again. Family loved this recipe. I doubled the portion and ran into a couple glitches. If you use more chicken than the recipe calls for you will probably need to spoon the fat out so you don't boil the meal! Also, when Chef John says high heat, it's high heat all the way through. It's the only way to ensure the sauce caramelizes. Once I had the liquids under control everything was perfect!
I don't know what I did wrong, but the glaze never came together. It wasn't a winner for my family.
Made this recipe many, many times...it’s DELISH!!!

item.name: Spicy Thai Basil Chicken (Pad Krapow Gai)
